description: From Middle English loser, losere, equivalent to lose +â€Ž -er. In the sense of contemptible or worthless individual, perhaps an alteration of losel, which see.

entries.meaning: A person who loses; one who fails to win or thrive.
examples: In a two-horse race there is always one winner and one loser.
He was always a good loser.

entries.meaning: A person who is frequently unsuccessful in life.
examples: That guy is a born loser!
I'm a constant loser in love.
Synonyms: crumb, (archaic) losel, louse; see also Thesaurus:worthless person

entries.meaning: One who or that which loses something, such as extra weight, car keys, etc.
A losing proposition, one that is likely to lose or already has lost (such as a losing bet or, analogously, a predictably fruitless task or errand).
(slang) A person convicted of a crime, especially more than once.
examples: He's a three-time loser doing twenty years.
